sub_title: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health at ITC, University of Twente
summary:
Dr. Carmen Anthonj is an Assistant Professor on GeoHealth at ITC. Her research focuses on water- and health-related infrastructure, knowledge and behaviour. She considers water and health challenges from a broader nexus perspective, including implications of inequality, extreme weather events, education, cultural context. She is interested in local knowledge, perspectives and perceptions of water- and health-related challenges and understanding how such local and contextualized knowledge can be used to inform public health planning and decision making. She conducts empirical mixed methods research from local to global level and with different stakeholders, and collaborates with international organizations, governments, local organizations and research institutes globally. Her regional focus is on Sub-Saharan Africa, South Pacific and Latin America.
  
Carmen Anthonj has a PhD in medical geography from the GeoHealth Centre at the Institute for Hygiene and Public Health ar the University Clinics of Bonn, Germany, and a Diplom in geography from the University of Bonn (focus on medical geography). She conducted postdoctoral studies at the Water Institute, Department of Environmental Sciences and Engineering at the Gillings School of Global Public Health at the University of North Carolina, US before joining ITC in 2020.

projects.title: WaSH Sector Monitoring in Pacific Island Countries with UNICEF Pacific
projects.description:
The Water Institute’s collaboration with the UNICEF Office for Pacific Island Countries aims to strengthen national WaSH systems (including monitoring) in Fiji, Kiribati, and the Solomon Islands. In Fiji and Kiribati, baseline data collection, analysis and reporting on WaSH in health care facilities takes place in collaboration with the Ministries of Health. In the Solomon Islands, data on WaSH in rural and urban households, WaSH in schools, and WaSH in health care facilities will inform programming and resource allocation by the Solomon Islands Government to improve WaSH service delivery.

Publications:

Anthonj, Tracy, Fleming, Shields, Tikoisuva, Kelly, Thakkar, Cronk, Overmars, Bartram, 2019. Geographical inequalities in drinking water in the Solomon Islands. STOTEN (accepted manuscript).

Fleming, Anthonj, Thakkar, Tikoisuva, Cronk, Kelly, Shields, Manga, Howard, Overmars, Bartram, 2019. Urban and rural sanitation and hygiene in the Solomon Islands: resilient to extreme weather events? STOTEN 683, 331-340.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health at ITC, University of Twente

projects.title: International Network on Household Water Treatment and Safe Storage
projects.description: The International Network on Household Water Treatment and Safe Storage, established in 2003 by the World Health Organization (WHO) and as of 2011 co-hosted by WHO and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), is an initiative bringing together over 100 key stakeholders worldwide to promote and scale up the adoption of practices and technologies that improve the quality of household drinking water for vulnerable populations. Established in 2003, the informal network format emphasizes flexibility, participation and creativity to support coordinated action.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health at ITC, University of Twente

projects.title: Community-based Nutrition and Integrated WaSH Program with UNICEF Ethiopia
projects.description:
With its large-scale rural Community-based Nutrition and Integrated WaSH Program, jointly implemented with the Government of Ethiopia (GoE), UNICEF Ethiopia aimed to address the combined risks of chronic malnutrition and poor access to basic WaSH services for 1.4 million people living in 30 woredas (districts) in four regions in Ethiopia, between 2011 and 2015. Researchers at the Water Institute at UNC, in collaboration with Jimma University, supported UNICEF Ethiopia with collection, analysis and reporting of data from 2,650 rural households, 2,400 children under age five, and 75 communities, and WaSH committees in WaSH intervention and control areas. The Water Institute’s collaboration and the baseline and midline results will help UNICEF Ethiopia to strengthen national WaSH systems, target program improvements, and allow them to measure their program outcomes and impacts.

Publications:

Anthonj, Fleming, Cronk, Godfrey, Ambelu, Bevan, Sozzi, Bartram, 2018. Improving monitoring and water point functionality in rural Ethiopia. Water 10 (11), 1591.

Anthonj, Fleming, Godfrey, Ambelu, Bevan, Cronk, Bartram, 2018. Health Risk Perceptions Are Associated with Domestic Use of Basic Water and Sanitation Services—Evidence from rural Ethiopia. International Journal of Environmental Research & Public Health 15 (10), 2112.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health at ITC, University of Twente

projects.title: GlobE Wetlands in East Africa. Reconciling future food production with environmental protection
projects.description:
Funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF), the project GlobE Wetlands in East Africa. Reconciling future food production with environmental protection focused on the sustainable use of wetlands in East Africa, aiming at increasing food production and security while minimizing negative effects on the environment. It analysed current wetland use systems for food production regarding processes, constraints, potentials and ecological trade-offs, compared major wetland use strategies for regional food security against the location-specific ecological, socio-economic and political boundary conditions, identified, assessed and targeted innovative (future) land use options at different scales and organizational levels and aimed at developing an integrated tool for the assessment and evaluation of wetland use options under regionalized scenarios of global change, while also providing guidance for wetland use planning and implementation of capacity building measures.

Publications:

Anthonj, Diekkrüger, Borgemeister, Kistemann, 2019. Health risk perceptions and local knowledge of water-related infectious disease exposure among Kenyan wetland communities. IJHEH 222 (1), 34-48.

Anthonj, Githinji, Kistemann, 2018. The impact of water on health and ill-health in a sub- Saharan African wetland:  Exploring both sides of the coin. STOTEN 624, 1411-1420.

Anthonj, Rechenburg, Höser, Kistemann, 2017. Contracting Infectious Diseases in Sub-Saharan African Wetlands: A Question of Use? A Review. IJHEH 220, 1110-1123

Anthonj, Rechenburg, Kistemann, 2016. Water, Sanitation and Hygiene in Wetlands. The Case of Ewaso Narok Swamp, Kenya. IJHEH 219 (7), 606-616.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health at ITC, University of Twente

projects.title: Water-related Information System for the Sustainable Development of the Mekong Delta, Vietnam (WISDOM)
projects.description:
Initiated by the German Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) and the Vietnamese Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST), the WISDOM Project was a bilateral research project between Germany and Vietnam, focusing on the creation of a Water-related Information System for the Mekong Delta between 2007 and 2013.

The main objective of the project was to collect information on the Mekong Delta from various fields, such as Hydrology, Geography and Earth Observation, Sociology, and to then integrate this information into a single Information System. The aim of this Information System was to provide a Decision Support System to the local, regional and national decision makers. Themes of research included quantification of water (floods, availability of water, water use), quality of water, land use and its change (moving from agriculture to aquaculture due to policies), climate change and mitigation, socio-economic aspects (educational standards, knowledge management, institutional and legal mapping).

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health at ITC, University of Twente

projects.title: KIBEX project on the vulnerability of critical infrastructure and civil protection to climate change related extreme weather events.
projects.description: The KIBEX project was conducted in cooperation with the German Aerospace Centre  as well as with the Postdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, and financed by the Federal Office for Civil Protection and Disaster Assistance. The aim of the KIBEX project was to assess the vulnerability of the population and critical infrastructure (KRITIS) to extreme weather events (torrential rain, heat waves, drought) as a result of the climate change. In addition to developing criteria and methods for vulnerability assessment, an appraisal of the possible consequences of cause-and-effect chains and interdependencies was also be carried out, the results of which will serve, among other purposes, as a basis for the development of adaptation measures to vulnerable populations.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health at ITC, University of Twente

projects.title: Multisectoral HIV and AIDS Response Programme, Multisectoral HIV Control
projects.description:
On behalf of the German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ), the Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) successfully partnered with the Namibian Ministry of Health and Social Services (MoHSS) to support the country’s multisectoral HIV and AIDS response from July 2011 to June 2016. During its lifespan the programme developed HIV prevention services and mobilised young men and women, employees and people living with HIV to actively use high-quality HIV prevention services adapted to their needs. These services were developed in collaboration with the public and private sectors, civil society and key stakeholders.

Publication:

Anthonj, Nkongolo, Schmitz, Hango, Kistemann, 2015. The Impact of Flooding on People living with HIV: a case study from the Ohangwena Region, Namibia. Global Health Action 8, 26441.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health at ITC, University of Twente

projects.title: GIZ Mekong River Commission (MRC) – Cooperation programme, Multinational Emergency Managment and Response Programme
projects.description: As part of the commitment of the Government of Germany and the Mekong River Commission on technical cooperation through GTZ to the MRC’s Flood Management and Mitigation Programme (FMMP), two components to improve the flood control policies of the MRC Member States bordering the lower Mekong as regards disaster management and land policy were supported. One component aimed to strengthen capacities for disaster management boost capacity in flood disaster management, and ensured the improvement of existing emergency management systems in riparian countries to deal with the Mekong floods more effectively, through capacity building, knowledge sharing and public awareness campaigns at the provincial, district and community levels. Another component aimed to improve land management techniques through the use of flood probability maps and addressed the issues of flood probability assessment techniques, improved land use planning methods and damage-reducing land management policies in order to achieve sustainable natural resource management in the Basin.

profile_positions.company: Faculty of Geo-Information Science and Earth Observation (ITC) of the University of Twente
profile_positions.description: Conducting research and lecturing on water- and health-related infrastructure, knowledge and behaviour. Considering water and health challenges, including water-related infectious disease exposure and provision of drinking water, sanitation and hygiene, from a broader nexus perspective, including implications of inequality, extreme weather events, education, cultural context. Interest in local knowledge, perspectives and perceptions of water- and health-related challenges and understanding how such local and contextualized knowledge can be used to inform public health planning and decision making. Conducting empirical mixed methods research from local to global level and with different stakeholders, and collaborating with international organizations, governments, local organizations and research institutes globally. Regional focus is on Sub-Saharan Africa, South Pacific and Latin America.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor GeoHealth with focus on Water and Health

profile_positions.description:
Research Associate at University of Edinburgh Business School to help understand collective action as response to COVID-19 in Colombia, Galapagos, Mexico. 

Study on economic consequences, coping mechanisms, local responses and collective action of vulnerable communities at risk of COVID-19, funded by the British Academy of Sciences.

Literature review and development of a theoretical framing on parallels between COVID-19 and climate change, the definition of unprecedented risks, vulnerability, risk adaption and mitigation.

Coding and analysis of qualitative in-depth key informant interviews with individuals and local leaders performing collective action in rural areas (Puebla, Mexico), informal urban settings (Medellin, Colombia) and islands (Galapagos, Ecuador).
profile_positions.title: Research Associate

profile_positions.description:
Postdoctoral Research Associate at the UNC Water Institute at the Gillings School of Global Public Health, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

Lead Researcher of WaSH Sector Monitoring in Pacific Island Countries project, funded by UNICEF Pacific, which aims to strengthen national WaSH systems (including monitoring) in Fiji, Kiribati, and the Solomon Islands in collaboration with the Ministries of Health. Baseline and census data analysis and reporting on WaSH in health care facilities in Fiji and Kiribati, baseline and census data analysis on WaSH in rural and urban households, and WaSH in schools in the Solomon Islands to inform programming and WaSH service delivery.

Researcher of Community-based Nutrition and WaSH Program, in collaboration with Jimma University, funded by UNICEF Ethiopia, to strengthen national WaSH systems, target program improvements, and measure program outcomes and impacts. Data analysis and reporting on rural households, communities, and WaSH committees in intervention and control areas.

Researcher on an Investment Case for Improving WaSH and Essential Environmental Conditions in Healthcare Facilities, funded by UNICEF. Reviews on healthcare-associated infections, WaSH interventions and care-seeking behaviour.

Network communications for International Network on Household Water Treatment and Safe Storage (HWTS), a World Health Organization and United Nations Children’s Fund initiative bringing together key stakeholders worldwide to promote and scale up the adoption of practices and technologies that improve the quality of household drinking water for vulnerable populations. Participants include UN agencies, development agencies, non-governmental organizations, research institutions, international professional associations and the private sector. 

Co-editor of the quarterly published WaSH Policy Research Digest, which aims to meet the evidence needs of in-country decision makers on topics related to rural water supply.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Research Associate

profile_positions.description: Comprehensive health, food security, water, sanitation and hygiene and climate change overview in a complex emergency setting in the North East of Nigeria. Research study for the Emergency Management Unit of the World Health Organization Nigeria.
profile_positions.title: Consultant

profile_positions.description: Associate researcher in the Department on Environmental Hygiene on international aspects of environment and health, focus on Sustainable Development Goals in the field of environment and health, environment and health in urban areas (national and international).
profile_positions.title: Research Associate

company.name: Institute for Hygiene and Public Health - WHO Collaborating Centre

profile_positions.company: Institute for Hygiene and Public Health - WHO Collaborating Centre
profile_positions.description:
Researcher in Prof. Dr. Thomas Kistemann's lab at the GeoHealth Centre, Institute for Hygiene and Public Health, University of Bonn. 

Focus on water, environment and health, on health-related risk assessment,  behaviour and perception, supervision of Msc and BA research projects in medicine, geography and public health, reviewer for scientific journals.

Part of the multidisciplinary and multinational research project GlobE Wetlands in East Africa - Reconciling future food production with environmental protection, a project, funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF).

Co-editor of the WHOCC Newsletter Water & Risk Issues 24 & 25.
